item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513) Remote Control: Final 3D Printed Part Added
item.description:

This piece fits into a 10mm opening on the remote control receiver board, allowing it to be secured using one of the main PCB’s screws. item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513) Remote Control: Now With a 3D Printed Installation Tray
item.description:
This post continues the discussion about my Beogram 4002 (5513) remote control upgrade, specifically the receiver board insulation. My previous solution, using plastic foil, wasn’t ideal aesthetically. To address this, I designed a plastic tray that safeguards the receiver board from the main circuit board’s solder points. The tray is designed to click into place without additional screws. item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513) Remote Control: Now With a Professionally Made PCB
item.description:
I recently had a professionally made circuit board manufactured for the remote control receiver in my Beogram 4002 (5513). It was exciting to see the new board arrive and start assembling it. The biggest changes in this design were simplifying the assembly by placing all the components on the top side and repositioning the ISP port to avoid interference with the aluminum top panel fixture. I also removed the reset button and made more space for the keypad connector...

item.title: An Early Christmas! Beosystem 6000 is in the House!
item.description:
Today, I took a 340-mile round trip to purchase a nearly perfect Beosystem 6000 from a fellow vintage audio enthusiast. It was a fantastic day! The Beogram 6000, complete with an MMC6000 cartridge, is in fantastic cosmetic shape. All the keypads look almost brand new, the veneer is in excellent condition, and it even includes replacement plexiglass components. It even came with all of the original owner’s manuals and service manuals, including the Beomaster 6000’s German “Technische Produktbeschreibung” (product description)!..
